description.text:
This is a simple bow tie I made for my high school prom.  I was originally going to simply use be3d_printers bow tie, however, my 3d printer absolutely hated making the bridges on that design.  My redesign avoids bridging as much as possible, and where it does, it has a large tolerance for error.  The end result was a hit and looks quite nice with a suit jacket or tux.    
Edit 1/24/2018  I meant to do this a long time ago but I never got around to it.  I updated the clip to follow the models actual scale.  I was really inexperienced when I made this!
I used PLA with 3 perimeters  and 100% infill.  I used a strap which I ripped off a cheap fake bow tie.  This slips between the tie and the tie clip during assembly.

description.text:
UPDATE [5/18/15] - Four button version is now available! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dEdVEQqoIJQ This is PiGRRL, a DIY gameboy. Look at it next to the new Pocket Pi GRRL - It’s like half the size, but just as powerful, with all sorts of retro games. This is a really fun project. You can learn about electronics and the raspberry pi by building one! Full Tutorial:
http://learn.adafruit.com/pocket-pigrrl/ We have a full tutorial on how to build this project on the adafruit learning site, it’s super fun! The Raspberry Pi A+ is small and adorable linux computer. The adafruit PiTFT is a 320x240 2.4’ display. This pi hat makes a great circuit sandwich! For the controls we’re using tactile switches and a Perma-Proto wired to a Pi Cable - Much better than hacking apart your Super Nintendo controller, save it for another project! To power this project, we're using the PowerBoost 1000c. It lets you charge while you’re playing - we’re calling it smart charging. 2000mAh of lithium gives you plenty of time to save that princess. How about that audio? 8-Bit never sounded so good with this tiny class-D amplifier and a mini metal speaker. Speaking of small, our 3D printed enclosure is even smaller than the original pocket gameboy. How do you like that BMO? Check out the Adafruit tutorial. You can get all the parts to build this project on the shop at adafruit dot com.
Check out the full tutorial on https://learn.adafruit.com/pocket-pigrrl/

comments.text: The instruction in the Adafruit webpage is clear enough, however there is a minor problem when configuring the GPIO/Key mapping for 4 buttons setting. In their setting, the button A is mapped to CTRL key and button y is mapped to Z key, which cause system crash when both button are pressed =P. A Ctrl-Z is sent and who knows which application was killed, anyway the Pi paused and a reboot is needed.

comments.text: I just had my Pocket PiGrrl shut down last night and a bad smell coming from inside. The tiny circuit board on the edge of the Adafruit LIPO battery was smoking. Keep an eye out on the battery wires because mine were not soldered correctly.

title: Clock Script for Reduced Friction (4 gears, 2 shafts)

description.text:
This is an alternate configuration for the printable clock, using four gears instead of eight, as well as some suggestions from rustedrobot and barrychuck (thanks guys!) to further reduce friction in the gear train, like only using concentric shafts to support the hands. It's also much faster to print, of course! :-) Because there are fewer gears, the 60:1 reduction is accomplished as 8x7.5 and the 12:1 reduction is accomplished as 4x3. This places some severe constrainst on the size of the gear hubs, but I think I managed to make everything fit. The downside in this trade-off is the size of the gear teeth, which is much smaller than in the 8-gear version. We'll have to see if it was worth it. This script relies on both the MCAD involute_gear library and on my own clockwork library. Current repository for the latest version of the clockwork library:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8155

Print one of each STL file, or fiddle with the script, check your work with assembled(), and then generate a new STL for each part with laidOutToPrint(), and print those.
The current configuration requires two shafts to slip the sleeved gears over, outer diameter 2mm with a clearance of half a millimeter either side, so M3 might work, depending on the print tolerances.
I'll hack up a frame for this soon, still working on improved frames for both clocks with rustedrobot.
The early adopters may want to pick a single gear or two, and print them out, just to see if the teeth are printable... ;-)
(EDIT: rev'd the script up to revB, just a fix to some of the echo() text, no changes to the actual clock parts)

For Parts 3,4

amp; 6 is it possible to remove the hollow tube (pinion) so that component is separate? If it could 'key lock' into the gear - it would print even faster. Z axis eats up all the machine time.... Selfish, I know - but just a thought.
comments.author: naveod

comments.text: Ah... good point. We'd need to print them as separate sleeves that interlock with the gear wheel hubs.
comments.author: naveod

comments.text: The biggest thing that slows down the print on the tubes for me is that I have the cool plugin turned on (slows down printing of small layers to give the plastic time to set). Having multiple tubes (3) building at the same time means that the machine should be able to print faster as the machine is already spending 3x as much time on each layer. Right now the tube portions generally take as much time as the entire gear section. That being said, I like them all-in-one for the simplicity of things.
comments.author: syvwlch

comments.text: Ok, sounds like a good candidate for a derivative if anyone is tempted? :-)
comments.author: rustedrobot

comments.text: I'd been thinking a little about the concentric shafts as well. Perhaps it might be possible to keep the concentric shafts, but separate them from the drive gear/drum gearset? That way it would be possible to provide a rigid mount for the gearset on the front of the frame to help constrain forces better against the gear teeth instead of deflecting the axel/colums.
comments.author: syvwlch

comments.text: Yup, we could put the hands on a separate shaft. Add'l gears means more friction, but they wouldn't be in the drive-train, which would then only have simple gearing running directly on metal.
comments.author: rustedrobot

comments.text: Another advantage of the separate shaft for the hands is that the extra gear can be used to slow down or speed up the hands compared to the nominal second/minute/hour gear in the drive train.
comments.author: syvwlch

comments.text: Or you could just glue the sleeves on afterwards? :-D

title: Kanto YU2 - 7.5 Degree Angle stand including port extension.

description.text:
This past Christmas I was given some wonderful Kanto YU2 powered speakers. Although the sound quality and volume exceeded my expectations I was unable to take advantage of the suggested positioning of the speakers so I created this stand which allowed me to direct that port forward without it being placed close to your back wall (http://i.imgur.com/aEXPduS.png). I built this design to use no supports and build in two separate pieces. After printing both parts use #6 self tapping plastic screws to attach both pieces. Isolation pads from your YU2 should be removed and attached to the bottom of the newly printed stands. You will need:
2 Printed (base.lower.stl)
2 Printed (base.upper.stl)
4 Purchased #6 Self Tapping Screws

This uses the spreadsheet from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7881 as a design table for a Solidworks part. Tested from 3 to 100 teeth at pressure angles of 14.5, 20 and 25deg. Currently only does straight spur gears, but it's really easy in Sldwrks to make an internal or helical gear. I realize only a minority of people on this site use Solidworks. I use it a lot, and I'm all that matters in the end :)

Open the part and edit the design table where you can change the module, number of teeth, pressure angle and profile offset (first 4 properties in the table). You can mess with more properties (addendum, dedendum, etc.) in the 'Calc' tab in the design table.

For the people like me who don't know what to do whit these files:
open the Gear_Blank file with Solidworks -> In the left toolbar thingy (history , sensors , annotations,material ... ) -> Click on the 3th page (looks like 2 boxes on a staircase) -> right mouse on "Tables" -> Hide / show tree items -> right mouse on "Design Table" -> click on "Edit Table" -> exel thingy opens inside of solidworks -> edit the tables you like -> click outside of the excel thing -> the item will regenerate and you have your gear.

I needed something that looked like a sci-fi shield for a cosplay and decided to take some inspiration from Fox's reflector.   
It is modeled after images from Super Smash Brothers for Wii-U by an industrial design student named Trisk.  
The light in the middle prints separately so it's easier to use a different colour filament or paint.

I printed it at 0.1mm layer height 15% infill with black PLA on a Velleman K8200. Took about 5 hours. The light in the middle prints separately so it's easier to paint or print in a different colour.  
Painted with acrylic paint, but rather in a hurry and without previous experience, so there might be better methods.  
The leather strap used to attach it to my belt was made by hand by a friend using fake leather.

A cutter to calm squirrels when hunting.
Inspired by: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oqCNyluDCUg UPDATE: Screw part was too thin, made a larger one.

For anyone doing a bathroom renovation or tub installation, you know (or soon will know) that you need to leave a 1/8" space between the flange and the framed wall.  
I've created a couple small parts to assist in that.  The first small piece are placement spacers that hook on the top of the flange between the tub and the stud.  That'll give you the correct spacing.  
Then, the second part is the permanent spacer that you'll install between the flange and your stud/screwing surface.  I've include a flexible tab at the top for ease of placement, then cut it away once you've drilled and screwed through the flange and through the hole in the spacer.  
I know they're pretty simple objects, but maybe it'll save someone else having to design it if they're doing a bath install.

Random bits sort box for screws or anything else small.  I made the insides of each sort section and the main front sort area curved to (hopefully) improve the ease of removing bits quickly.  It can also be connected to another sort box to make a mega sort box, or connected to two for a super-mega sort box.
This passed ReplicatorG gcode generation, but as I have no printer (yet) it is untested.
This was built in Google Sketchup and was a giant pain to remove all the interior extras that got left behind from modeling so Skeinforge would stop saying "this should never happen" errors over and over.
Update #1: I modified the sort box (sortboxb.stl) to have a deeper front sort area mostly to reduce the amount of plastic used.
Update #2: Added top for the smaller individual sort areas (passed gcode generation).
You need to scale this down by 0.01 to get the correct size.

title: Apple Watch and iPhone 5, 6/6+ and 7/7+ Dock

description.text:
I like to keep my bedside tidy and to have two docks would make it a little messy so I've designed a combined dock which allows one or both devices to charge.  
I have a 0.3mm clear TPU case on my iPhone shouldn't make much difference without.  
Pictured: iPhone 6 plus and Apple Watch Sport 42mm  
Any modification in which you would like let me know.  
Edit 09.05.2015:  
It seems as though the manufacturing tolerances on the two types of charger are different and there is an approximate 0.25mm difference.  
So for each file there is and Apple Watch Sport and an Apple Watch Stainless Steel.  
Also I have uploaded an iPhone 5/5s model. I would appreciate anyone who makes it to leave feedback as I don't own an iPhone 5.

0.2mm Layer height.
2 shells.
15% Infill.

description.text: Buisness Logo Clothing Labels

These are spring feet that fit on the bottom of a RepRap machine to damp the transmission of vibrations from the machine to whatever surface it is resting on.
If that surface is resonant, a RepRap machine without these feet can make quite a bit of noise.  These reduce that noise significantly.

Print two of the feet with projections on the bottom, and two of the ones without.
The ones with the projections fit under the higher bottom threaded-rod clamps on one diagonal, the no-projection ones fit under the other diagonal.
These are designed to be printed on their side, so that they look like a letter Z when viewed from above.

description.text:
Printable snap-together tank with electronics. This design is a collaboration between my company http://newbound.com and NBitWonder. First off, the list of things this is a derivative of:

  • My original tank design http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6554

  • Tracks Chain and Pinions by foxdewayne http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5690

  • Chain and Pinions by aubenc http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5656

  • Large Threaded Bolt and Nut by ub3rgeek http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4880

  • Parameterized battery pack with contacts by obijuan http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5079

  • Parameterized Battery Compartment by guru http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5051

  • My original 9 Volt Racer http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4818
    • The circuit board may have been updated since the version on thingiverse http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7618. Download the latest version from github https://github.com/NBitWonder/DCMotorController. The parts are individually laid out in layer 2 of tank.blend. The tank.stl is really just for the pretty render and is not useful for printing. UPDATE: The motors I chose for this project ended up not having enough torque to drive the treads. The motors ended up getting used for the successor to the Tank line-- the Truckbot line: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10349

You will also need 16 nuts (3mm) for the battery contacts, some wire, 8 AA batteries and a pair of 600 RPM DC motors http://www.batteryspace.com/dcmotorhightorquemini12vdcgearmotor600rpmforhobbyproject.aspx. Print out the following: 4 x axel-end.stl 2 x axel-gear.stl 4 x axel-spacer.stl 4 x axel.stl 8 x axelholder.stl 2 x battery.stl 4 x elbow.stl 2 x motorholder.stl 1 x pcb-holder-mirror.stl 1 x pcb-holder.stl 12 x plus.stl 16 x short-axel.stl 32 x tank-tread-1-single.stl 32 x tank-tread-2-single.stl 8 x wheel.stl 4 x worm-end.stl 2 x worm-gear.stl 2 x wormholder-mirror.stl 2 x wormholder.stl Assemble as depicted in tank.stl or tank.blend. You will find that the motors need to be mounted to the motor holders PRIOR to assembly or you won't be able to bolt them in. The battery holders should be wired up prior to mounting as well. Build the PCB https://github.com/NBitWonder/DCMotorController and mount it to the pcb holders. Add some wiring to connect the PCB to the batteries and motors and then figure out how to control the darn thing with that last-generation ipod or smartphone you've got laying around collecting dust...

description.text:
I built the open source MONOCHRON clock designed by Lady Ada:
http://www.ladyada.net/make/monochron/index.html
I built it on perfboard using a KS0108-display and parts I already had. Note that my display is smaller than the display from the kit. I built the clock two years ago and now that I have a 3D-printer I could finally create a nice casing for it!

First check that your display fits the window of the casing. If not, re-size the model in the STL-file or edit the SketchUp design. Then create the MONOCHRON clock using perfboard and the instructions you can find online at:
http://www.ladyada.net/make/monochron/index.html
Now print the casing. Insert the perfboard and display. Insert the push buttons and power connector and solder it together. Close the casing using four M3 bolts. You do not need nuts for the bolts, the holes in the casing are just the right size to hold the M3 bolts. Connect a power supply and enjoy your clock!

comments.text: Just to give a counterpoint, I just printed this and with good bed adhesion (wipe down your painter's tape w/ acetone to clean it up.  It'll stick like you wouldn't believe) I had no problems whatsover with tipping or falling.  In PLA it came out very flexible and still quite strong.  On the male part I can squeeze the outer pins all the way to the center pin with no threat of breaking.  I did make sure to orient it so the layers ran the length of the male clip.  If it was printed upright (z axis longest) I could see how it would break much more easily along the layer lines as the clips flexed.

title: Raspberry PI Case With Serial DB9 Connector

description.text:
Just a little more room please.  
This is based on the RPI House by OxyJin. I liked this version because it is very easy to assemble and disassemble while there are other peripherals connected to the Raspberry Pi.   
It is difficult to find a ready made case out there with just bit more head room for Raspberry Pi expansions. I have yet to see one for a serial connection.  
This final product in the pictures is a device server to capture serial prints and store them as individual PDF files. It will also convert the serial to Ethernet for network printing. An RTC (Real Time Clock) can be added because of the extra room.  
I added a section of the drawing to acommodate for the AB Elelctronics RS232 and 1 wire peripheral. I ordered this just before they released a new version with just the RS232 connector.   
The next may include this new version with an Real Time Clock addon. They stack up and I will need to increase the height.  
Update: New pictures were added to include the AB Electronics DB9 (DSUB) RS232 converter. It is also a higher case to add the RTC clocks they provide to stack above the RS232 board. I will add the MOSHI Soft drawing and PDF soon for the new case.

This case is 1cm higher and the expansion slot was removed. The intention is to have an enclosed "all in one" package with no external cables or boards. The CAD drawing is setup to use common acrylic .093 panels from a popular home improvement store. The slots are resized to 2.05mm width. All the interlocking panels have a firm fit. The top is also slightly bowed to keep it a bit more together. The curve is not noticeable unless you look at it down the line. K40 40W Laser at 10mA controlled by a Chris Circuits board
Mach3 set at a speed of 300 units.

Hand Crank for Yet Another Printable Spool

Press onto spool for easy loading. I used the original version to load a spool with filament but the crank handle kept slipping off under load, it would have been fine if I was using it with the spool mounted horizontally, but mounted vertically, there's too much sideways (downward) pressure. I have now increased the lugs that extend into the spool and slightly narrowed the gap at the base so that the crank clips into place and does not pull off so easily.
The revised version is much better and is hard to remove from the spool during use. The 0.5mm lugs I added made all the difference!

This is the clip that goes on the back of the 2nd row seat for 2001-2006 Suburbans.  It holds the floor panel up when the seat is not folded down.  Mine broke, so I designed a replacement in TinkerCad.  
May work for other makes/models as well.  
You can print as oriented above with no supports, but I highly recommend printing on the left side for better strength, with hemispherical part toward the top.  This should print fine without supports as well, and will be stronger.

comments.text: Thank you! Works great... I had modeled this on my own a while back but yours is much better, and thanks for the tip of printing on the side.

comments.text: Thanks.  My only problem has been that after some time, the spring will break through and it stops holding the seat back without the spring tension.  The spring wire is so thin, and presses strongly against the back of the clip, eventually it wears a hole between two layers and starts to poke through the other side.  Printing in different orientations to get the "grain" right might help.

The reduced version doesn't slice either? Then you need a better slicer ;-)
I can do it for you and give you a fish but I rather give you a fishing rod: try the free program MeshMixer - it's wonderful! I am working on a "semi-automatic pond refiller" project, and this model is part of the water level sensor component.   
This is a "capsule" for a Sharp GP2Y0A21 Infrared Sensor I already have lying around the house from a previous robotics project.   
I added a cylindrical shell on the outer rim so I can heatshrink the sensor wires and make it (hopefully) water resistant. The sensor itself is mounted on a PCB, with a plastic lens formed into the outer casing, so I am not worried about water getting in through the rectangular slot at the top.   
The screw holes are pretty arbitrary; I was hoping to dig through a box of random screws and find one to fit, rather than tailor the holes the screw. The two holes to mount the sensor (little "ear" cutouts) should be 3.36mm, if that helps.  
Edit: I ended up using some 4mm diameter by 25mm length screws, and adjusted the threads accordingly. I removed the outer cable support, since it seemed unnecessary and didn't print well without additional supports. The fitted cylinder "guides" were also removed when I added the three screw holes.

description.text:
Print a mold for a floating candle! STL contains two identical halves which form a single mold.
Note: Requires some work after printing.

After printing, sand the inside of the mold and coat it with epoxy to get a smooth finish. Clamp together and pour in the wax at around 160F - much higher and the PLA will melt!  
Don't forget the wick!  
If you prepared the inside sufficiently, it comes out smoothly and easily. The rocking action permitted by the mold teeth was extremely effective.  
See my blog at wgprojects.blogspot.com for more details.

I used the Sharp product documentation's dimensions to create a CAD file of a hobby infrared distance-measuring sensor (Sharp GP2Y0A21). NOTE: This is not a functioning infrared sensor, but instead a reference model for others to use. Most of the measurements are exactly as listed by Sharp, but there were some specifications which weren't published, like the height of the white pcb connector, the angle and dimensions of the back of the connector; and I found that the height of the main base was not as listed in the product specifications. (actually ~7mm, versus the 9.2 listed) Edit: Just got some digital calipers in the mail today, and I will try to re-do some of the guestimated measurements, to make the model more precise

In the endless war of gardener versus squirrel, I'm experimenting this year with an electric fence.  
In my implementation, I've put a 3-feet-tall chicken wire fence around my tomato bed with an aluminum wire running just above the top of the fence. The aluminum wire is hot and the chicken wire is connected to the ground terminal of the fence charger. In theory, a squirrel that attempts to climb the fence will get a shock when it reaches the top wire.  
To keep the wire isolated from the fence, while also keeping it close enough to keep a squirrel from going under the wire, I designed this little clip to connect the fence and wire at regular intervals.  
In a few weeks, with any luck, I'll be eating all the tomatoes I can stand and posting hilarious squirrel videos to YouTube.
Designed in Tinkercad. Printed in natural PLA, .2 mm height. 20% fill. I haven't yet tested on an energized fence.

comments.text: I have probems with my electric fencing shorting out on the barbwire around a few of the pens on my farm.  Before I design a standoff myself I figured I would try this one.  I printed 10 out on a raft and they seemed to print okay.  I will install them tomorrow and report back :-)
